conclusion: Understanding the problem about an ideal gas changing states and finding work done from B to C.
Point A is at pressure P₀ and volume V₀; Point B is at pressure 0.6P₀ and volume V₀; Point C is at pressure 0.6P₀ and volume 0.5V₀.
Gas starts at state A with P₀, V₀, T₀ and goes to state C with 0.6P₀, 0.5V₀.
Question asks for work done from state B to state C.
Path from A to B: Pressure decreases from P₀ to 0.6P₀ at constant volume V₀; From B to C: Volume decreases from V₀ to 0.5V₀ at constant pressure 0.6P₀.
Work done by gas is given by the integral of P dV.
For constant pressure process B to C, work done is P * ΔV.
Negative sign indicates work is done on the gas.
In thermodynamics, work done by the system is positive, work done on the system is negative.
Since gas is compressing from B to C, work done by the gas is negative: W = -0.3P₀V₀.
Internal energy U = aT; internal energy depends on temperature for ideal gas.
Find temperature at points B and C using ideal gas law.
At point B, T_B = 0.6T₀; At point C, T_C = 0.3T₀.
Temperature decreases from 0.6T₀ to 0.3T₀ from B to C.
Change in internal energy ΔU = a(0.3T₀ - 0.6T₀) = -0.3aT₀.
ΔU = Q - W; Q is heat added, W is work done by system.
Total work from A to C is W_A_to_C = W_A_to_B + W_B_to_C.
